div.head: To the gentle Reader.
div.p:
IT is a usuall manner in many parts where wayes bee doubtfull, for a Traveller to finde a standing past with a hand to direct men the ready way, but those hands tell thee not how many miles, nor the distance from place to place, whereby many a man, not knowing the distance, or how to cost the Country, is benighted and loseth his way; nay sometimes his life: yet I must confesse, it is an excellent comfort such a post that rides not, should give directions to the ryder Post: but here is a messenger which will goe with that, and direct thee from place to place, without any great charge: nay it is such a director, that I daresay, had it beene found out the last great Snow, it had saved many a man 〈…〉
ney, nay some their lives. Now for thy good (gentle reader) this hath beene composed and gathered with much paines and industry, and that not slightly, but in the best order to accommodate thee in that manner, that you shall thinke your money well best •• ed, and give the Author thankes, and thee all content in that kinde iustly travell, and so I leave thee to further directions, as the table shewes.
